author: {'steamid': '76561198022527186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 2682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2682, 'last_played': 1643564473}
review:
[h1]Hoofit dies young[/h1]

[b]What is Die Young[/b]
Itâ€™s a survival game in the literal sense of the world. You play a young woman called Daphne who is stuck on an island and is attempting to find her friends and escape. As beautiful as the island is, it is full of dangerous wildlife, and people that wish to seek you harm. You will need to eat, keep hydrated and sleep, failing to do the last two will kill you. As well as finding and making weapons, handy equipment and maybe even finding some of the very rare wearable items that are â€˜hiddenâ€™ across the island. There is definite item resource management going on.

Iâ€™ve seen it described as a survival horror and I can see why, there are some unpleasant people/things that go on, but itâ€™s not like resident evil where its constant, or thatâ€™s a part of the gameâ€™s soul. Most of the island is pretty and thereâ€™s even friendly villagers, thereâ€™s even large parts of it where you can just relax. Whilst there are bad things, thereâ€™s only really a couple of places, later on where horrifying things have happened/are happening.

I would call it survival exploration, the exploration of which involves a lot of parkouring- jumping on/off things climbing etc. There are a lot of places to visit, landmarks to visit and locations to explore. And yeah, you do a LOT of climbing and jumping, most of which involve some level of risk including falling to your doom. One tip learnt from experience, jump about a second after you think you should- as thereâ€™s a bit of leeway and it helps to make those tricker jumps!



[b]Die Young as a â€˜trueâ€™ open world[/b]
You have total freedom to explore in that whilst you have to rest at night, you can take as much time as you want, in the main, exploring that ruin, finding out what has been happening in the story, hunting for ancient idols (the games only collectible) etc. Itâ€™s an open world game in its truest sense in that you have a whole island to explore, at your own pace, with but a few non-respawning enemies. As opposed to a Ubisoft open world which has millions of collectibles, upgrades, and area progress status bars.

Itâ€™s also quite unique in that it doesnâ€™t hold your hand, so whilst thereâ€™s notes and clues and there are quests, it doesnâ€™t really advise you where to go, when. There are locations with really useful items, and ones without, and you may stumble into a really useful item, or miss an almost critical one and not be the wiser. There are a few upgrades which are really helpful but you may miss how to make them without having done a very specific thing.

Instead, itâ€™s up to you explore, follow quests, or not (they donâ€™t give experience, more of that later) avoid/fight animals and guards, gather loot and expand your backpack (critical). I strongly advise you find a backpack as soon as is possible and then make more upgrades, itâ€™s a lifesaver as thereâ€™s a lot of gear you will want to hold.

The one collectible (ancient idols) arenâ€™t massively well explained, and thereâ€™s little way of knowing where they are unless you look at a guide. Any indoor location where thereâ€™s a hard bit to get to may have one. Whilst you donâ€™t need to collect all you will need a few for buying poisoned bolts which I class as essential. 

When you do a quest for a man named the collector, you can then buy items with the idols and after doing so you then learn how to make them. Others highly recommend the harpoon and there are other good ones too, but seriously save some for poisoned bolts which become available late-game. And save some bolts for the ending.


[b]Upgrades, crafting and experience[/b]
Another big difference from the triple A open worldâ€™s is that there is much less crafting and upgrades. You learn to make various weapons, medi-kits, drugs and equipment but really there isnâ€™t a huge amount. I donâ€™t mind this, thereâ€™s enough useful stuff to make without drowning you in options. Be aware there isnâ€™t trial and error crafting, you learn a recipe by story, finding the recipe or buying off the collector. You canâ€™t upgrade your weapons, but can increase your storage amounts.

There are inventory slots but most slots like hands have one or two items. I donâ€™t mind this, it makes the game less about gear management and more about just playing, but if you love picking through items and deciding what is optimal for you, then this might be a draw-back. This is a game where you can choose climbing gloves or gardening gloves.

Speaking of which there are no levels, experience or skill trees. Daphne never reaches level 2 or learns a hunting skill, nor does she inexplicably get stronger. You will get better gear and actually threatening weapons but Daphne wonâ€™t improve at an arbitrary level. If you will forgive my literary flourish, you as a player will level up, the jumps which at first saw plenty of me falling to my death, become easier to make. Combat you will figure out (sneak up, bash, then circle strafe worked for me) and even though I didnâ€™t have more stamina and strength points I felt like I had levelled up.



[b]How does it look and play[/b]
Honestly Die Youngâ€™s island is beautiful, whilst there are glitches (Iâ€™ll come onto that) and the character models are a little basic and lacking in variety, the island and its locations are great to look at. Take time to explore and admire the view from up high and youâ€™ll love it, spend time thinking why do all the guards have bizarre bandannas and look like theyâ€™ve been cloned from one of the same 2 men and you wonâ€™t. 

There are glitches, people have reported clipping of modelâ€™s, bodies sometimes die and then drop inexplicably into difficult/impassable terrain. My game was mostly free of that, though I did have one guard who I killed on top of a tower fall through it and off a cliff, thankfully I did not need his weapon! What I did however is the standing up dead people bug. Basically, any guard I killed later on would when I left the area stand back up again and only collapse back when I got close to them. Spooky!

It plays quite well. The parkouring is generally intuitive and itâ€™s great to get the top of a tower/building and be able to see for miles. It took me a bit of learning but Iâ€™m not the worldâ€™s greatest platformer. Combat is extremely basic with a limited stealth system and not much variety in moves. I just snuck up behind people to get the first blow then circle strafed like a mad man. When you get a crossbow, the game becomes 10X easier and thatâ€™s not much of an exaggeration. Iâ€™d recommend you leave bosses well alone until you get the crossbow when itâ€™s open season.


[b]Hoofit's finishing thoughts[/b]
I have recommended this game. Itâ€™s not flawless but for a cheaper price indie game thatâ€™s perhaps a bit much to expect. Itâ€™s limited in some ways for good (not drowned in useless options/upgrades) and in some ways for bad; you canâ€™t look at the map outside of the region youâ€™re in. The glitches may bother some, and the combat is just something you have to get through until you get a crossbow.

But it is an interesting island which whilst the end goal is to escape from it, my goal was to explore, find out what happened and look at the beautiful sea from places I had climbed to. Itâ€™s sold at an affordable price, certainly compared to AAA games, and it felt good to level up as a person not by killing dogs for experience. 

You do need a bit of stubbornness on some of the harder parkouring bits, have to want to explore and itâ€™s a game where you can really come a cropper at the end if you havenâ€™t got the right recipe. But still for the price itâ€™s well worth your time, and itâ€™s still being supported by the developers, a good purchase, and a great one on sale!

[b]Oh, and save regularly and start in adventure mode until you get more confident.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561199005834090', 'num_games_owned': 1334, 'num_reviews': 205, 'playtime_forever': 1604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1483, 'last_played': 1643760155}
review:
Die Young is a hidden gem that you probably never heard of , a well crafted game with style and elements i haven't seen in a game before , despite me being enjoying this game , i gotta point out this game isn't for everyone.

so what is this game? its simply an adventure FPS consists of survival and crafting/heavy exploration/parkour platforming/melee combat ,, you play as a rich spoiled girl who went to an uncharted island with her friends to spend their vacation to have fun and explore , being kidnapped along with her friends by the natives , you wake up in a well and try to find help.

so whats so special about this game? its no joke , the game treats you exactly like what a lost person on an island is like , and that what makes its it so intense and intimidating , you need to find water to stay alive , scrap to make weapons , explore the areas thoroughly to know what to do , it doesn't hold your hand at all , if you miss a crafting recipe or a weapons in an area the game doesn't tell you (unless its a story related).

the game also a nice progression system , the more you dive deep , the more things changes , the protagonist becomes more ruthless the more people she kill , you find better weapons , better cloths to preform tasks and so on , the game takes a more stealthy approach towards enemies due to the fact you are playing with someone with no experience in combat , but you can go loud if you feel confident , the game has block/dodge system at your disposal.

the island is also huge , there is tons of areas to explore , which are most of the are optional but very rewarding , there is a map and a fast travel system which can be unlocked early on , the map is confusing at first but when you start to draw the lines and checking your journal usually to know what to do you will handle it.

what i didn't like
i'm sorry but the voice acting is awful , not average or mediocre , just awful , none of the characters did a good job in talking or presenting themselves , i am aware the game was on a budget , but the voice actors just don't fit well with their characters 

the boss fights are more than an exploit fights than an actual fight , cause you need to cheese the fight to win them , due to the fact how much damage can take and how much damage they can hammer you with , the normal enemies are fine cause you can dodge and block , but the bosses take far to long time for this strategy.

another note : the game comes with another free game called Die Young : Prologue , which i did play first before the main game thinking it will be an introduction for the game , but its actually not , its more of a demo of the main game that has nothing to do with it 'narrative-ly' , its takes place in the same island though.

finally i would like to say i mostly enjoyed the game with what it had to offer despite these small drawbacks , i also never played like it before , i played games like Dying Light and The Forest which share some elements , but the experience here is unique and a first time for me, also the price is more than convenient for the content.

review:
[h1] Un jeu au potentiel inexploitÃ© [/h1] 

(JouÃ© sous Linux avec la surcouche Proton)
Die young est un jeu dâ€™aventure qui rappelle les derniers Tomb Raider et un peu Dying light. On y incarne DaphnÃ©, une jeune femme qui se retrouve prisonniÃ¨re dâ€™une Ã®le Ã  la recherche de ses amies. Lâ€™Ã®le est dÃ©coupÃ©e en 3 parties bien distinctes. Câ€™est un jeu immersif qui mÃ©rite que lâ€™on sâ€™y attarde.

 [h1] Points fortsÂ : [/h1] 
â†’ Le personnage principal, DaphnÃ©, est un personnage attachant.
â†’ La faune complexeÂ : des sangliers qui chargent quand ils te voient, des serpents venimeux fourbent dans les fourrÃ©esâ€¦
â†’Lâ€™atmosphÃ¨re rÃ©ussie, avec des documents dissimilÃ©s un peu partout.
â†’ Les phases de plates-formes.
â†’ Lâ€™Ã©quipement trouvÃ© un peu partout.
â†’ La durÃ©e de vie honnÃªte, jâ€™ai mis une bonne trentaine de jeu (soit deux jours dans le jeu) en prenant, vraiment tout mon temps, car, jâ€™aime bien faire le jeu au maximum (jâ€™ai juste ratÃ© la cachette dâ€™AndrÃ© et un lieu de stockage).
â†’ Les musiques.
â†’ La gestion de la soif.
â†’ Les Ã©nigmes.
â†’ Lâ€™histoire.
â†’ 3 fins diffÃ©rentes.
â†’ Le prix.
â†’ Lâ€™excellente traduction faite par le joueur Ulfric Sombrage (merci Ã  lui)
â†’ Fonctionne trÃ¨s bien sous Linux avec Proton.

 [h1] Points faiblesÂ : [/h1] 
â†’ Une premiÃ¨re partie de lâ€™Ã®le dÃ©serte. On nâ€™y croise pas grand monde.
â†’ Lâ€™IA ridicule. On se fait repÃ©rer, si on est dans des hautes herbes, on sâ€™accroupit et on nâ€™est plus dÃ©tectÃ©.
â†’ Les phases dâ€™infiltrations sont limitÃ©es.
â†’ Beaucoup de va-et-viens entre les diffÃ©rentes zones.
â†’ Le systÃ¨me de combat, pas adaptÃ©. Il est difficile dâ€™esquiver.
â†’ Les chiens.
â†’ Les â€œzombiesâ€ trop peu nombreux.
â†’ Des zones inaccessibles (je pense Ã  cette immense porte prÃ¨s dâ€™un brasier)
â†’ Les cut-scÃ¨nes ne fonctionnent pas sous Linux.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002684948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1642370165}
review:
Bon j'ai jouer et fini le prologue.... c'Ã©tait pas foufou mais ca se fait tranquillou et c'Ã©tait plus ou moins agrÃ©able comme expÃ©rience de jeu.
Par contre la version "officielle" ben je me suis fais .... chier...

l'IA est toujours aussi peu intelligente, les pauvres rottweiller (qui hurle comme des loups?) font des bonds de cotÃ© pour Ã©viter nos coups.... mais encore.... les "droguÃ©s?" qui nous voit en plein milieu d'une plaine vous perdent de vue si on fait 3 mÃ¨tres de recul... mouais

Le truc le plus chiant Ã  mon gout restera l'exploration de l'ile.... 
Les interminables phases de sauts chiantes pour arriver sur une plateforme avec une porte fermÃ©e... des longues minutes Ã  marcher pour arriver Ã  une porte clause... Ã  chercher une arme qu'on trouvera au milieu d'un champs sans aucune explication.... 
Les quÃªtes indiquent de suivre un certain cheminement mais malheureusement les objets que ce cheminement implique ne sont pas sur ce "trajet".... donc.... ben faut fouiller l'ile... donc ....autant pas faire cette quÃªte de cheminement alors!!!

Les graphismes sont pas horribles, voir meme agrÃ©able concernant le paysage (les humanoides moyen moyen....)

donc je ne poursuivrai pas plus loin cette aventure... je pense que la suite et l'histoire doit Ãªtre sympa mais le cotÃ© yamakasi Ã  devoir sauter de partout (et refaire car on tombe souvent), grimper une falaise pour voir qu'il faut passer de l'autre cotÃ© car pas de chemin.... toujours devoir grimper, escalader, tomber, mourir, refaire m'a gaver.
Les bruitages... au fait.... ben pas gÃ©niaux non plus hein.... jamais vu des renards ou des rotts faire ca :D
Dommage car le prologue avait su me captiver car tout aussi linÃ©aire mais beaucoup plus logique dans le cheminement.

je dirais quand mÃªme 10/20 car je pense qu'il manque pas grand chose pour le rendre moins relou et faisable avec envie

author: {'steamid': '76561198010529464', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 3817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1722, 'last_played': 1641696124}
review:
I was in two minds about Die Young for quite a while; would it be a game that I recommended with EXTREME reservations, or one I simply couldn't recommend? Well, jury's back, verdict is in. I can't recommend a game in which a set piece boss takes no damage from powerful weapons simply because the devs don't think that my character should possess said weapon at that time. Really, really can't get with this outcome, as it's so contrived and reality-breaking. I'll likely try to finish the game, but it has serious problems with graphics (I am seeing horrible pixels in the sky, for example, on a 1080 Ti running on an i7 machine), climbing mechanics, and consumables stacking on top of the experience shattering bad puzzles. It's frankly a no-go for me. Very glad I got it during the winter sale.

Note: I read that the devs actually patched out better and more logical ways to kill or avoid the dog. Really terrible, ludicrous game design. SMH.

author: {'steamid': '76561198214378672', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1710, 'last_played': 1645374080}
review:
Okay, it's finally time to make a genuine review about this game.
Die Young is a decent survival / horror game, it's not one of those games that scare you.
It is one of those games that sometimes give you weired out / creepy vibes.
To me, personally. It's been very good 28.5 hours of gaming. When I first played it I've been going through a break up.
This game helped me clear my mind and gave me the motivation I needed.
I am very grateful to IndieGala / the game devs for that...

author: {'steamid': '76561198061197146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1057, 'last_played': 1641179241}
review:
This game is fantastic, right up to the final moment. But then the devs decided to completely change the game play (entirely without warning, I might add) and you end up hopelessly unprepared to finish the game.

*SPOILERS AHEAD*


For the entirety of the game, you have to rely on stealth and quietly get the upper hand on unsuspecting enemies. But in the final moment of the game, you're pitted against 12 to 18 enemies (a mix of snipers and melee attackers), alongside an aggressively overpowered final boss.  There's a really good chance you won't have enough weapons or healing items to survive, because you get ZERO warning. The stealth techniques you mastered through the rest of the game are useless against the boss. A single attack from a hidden location, and all the enemies know exactly where you are.  The game switches from a stealth platformer to a first person shooter, but your character remains a weak rogue without the defence or HP to survive the ordeal.
I will never understand why the developers decided to do this!  They completely ruined a game that I've put nearly 20 hours into by pulling the rug out from under my feet!

author: {'steamid': '76561198815748328', 'num_games_owned': 2991, 'num_reviews': 710, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1640598857}
review:
"What if Far Cry 3, but your PC isn't a psychopath?"
I'm not a fan of open-world-survival-crafting but so far it hasn't annoyed me HUGELY.  The initial carry capacity is pretty annoying.  You can carry about 6 things, and once you've picked up a couple of essential tools, that doesn't leave much room for healing items.
There are pre-designed areas with pre-designed linear traversal paths, rather than just a huge randomly-generated map of generic boring stuff.  This is good.  Combined with a bad initial map, it gives a "aim for a distant landmark, but get distracted by unexpected areas on the way" goodfeels of Skyrim and Fallout.
Purchase includes a "prologue" game where you get the crossbow right away.  The other commenters are right, it's game-breakingly good, even if the iron sights are a pain.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974627682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 1393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1393, 'last_played': 1640024771}
review:
[h1]Ambitious jank, aka how to try to build Dying light and Forest with fraction of the budget needed[/h1]

You start the game, everything feels janky - the game doesn't look "awful" per say, but it's clear that the budget wasn't the highest. Audio is awkward, presentation is... indie, and you feel awkward trying to adjust to the game. You either keep pushing forward, or like 90% of the players, drop out at some point without finishing it.

[u]The good [/u] 

[list]
[*]Rewarding exploration - this is the meat and bones of the game - not combat, but exploration and platforming. It feels great to progress through areas by solving simple enviromental puzzles, every location is unique (there aren't that many) and you are generally rewarded by snooping around. It's the game's strongest part, without this, I probably wouldn't bother.
[*]For a thrift shop version of parkour from Dying Light, it's not bad. And you will be doing a lot of it.
[*]Lots of nice details - as you explore, you unlock little ways to be able to backtrack easily.
[*]Not everything is out there to get you, some animals will fight back, but not unless provoked, makes the world feel a bit more organic.
[*]The world they made is appealing, locations change and are generally well made.
[*]Plenty of optional objectives that are fun to do, because they tie to the best aspect, the exploration and enviromental puzzles. You will get a better understanding of the story as well.
[*]All right crafting progression - some things are meaningful, others feel incomplete (generic increase of backpack space).
[/list]

You keep pressing forward, enjoying the exploration, the enviroments, at times abusing systems, whenever it's the AI, or map design, and you continue. The exploration is highly rewarded.

[u]The not so good [/u] 

[list]
[*]Animals are just bonkers, they slide around like nothing, in first few hours, you will question if this was somebody's college project.
[*]Lack of clear progression, the further you get, the more convoluted and unfinished the game gets - last third is just messy, and by the end of the game, I had enough of it's mazes and nonsensical map designs
[*]Confusing and messy level design, especially towards the last third of the game, you can really feel they didn't have enough time or money - I almost lost my mind climbing the mountain, it's a huge area with so many optional little pathways and it's overwhelming.
[*]Combat is... functional. In contrast to your character being amazingly athletic, you suck at fighting - which is fine, I get that the game is trying to encourage you to stay away from combat, but this isn't utilized at all. The enemies are dumb, they do not respawn (thank god), so in the end, I just killed everyone rather than having to deal with questionable stealth. There is some learning curve, but it's certainly not great.
[*]Pretty bad dialogue most of the times - the game can't decide whenever it wants to be serious or not, your character may react in horror while seeing a mauled body, or she will give it a "witty" one-liner like she's from a cartoon.
[/list]

Then admittedly, something amazing happens, the reason why we play jank games - you begin feeling more confident, comfortable in an intimidating game that felt awkward - it's still bit awkward, but you feel in control - this level of satisfying progression, which happens within your abilities, since it's you who's learning, is something hardly found in AAA games, because they know the casual audience (which makes them the most money) isn't willing to put up with any struggle.

[u]The ugly [/u] 

[list]
[*]Awful audio engineering (some sounds are much louder, like Foxes screaming), in some places the music switches between several tracks, back and forth like 10 times in 30 seconds, it's a shame, because some tracks are quite nice. Also I haven't heard most of the songs featured in credits... where are they?
[*]The most awkward and assinine map I've ever seen - apparently the team didn't know how to program scrolling... your character marks every source of water, but you don't mark any locked doors or anything that would help with progress - oh and the map just gives you general sense of direction, forget about helping you navigate through the more confusing areas.
[*]Awful performance at times - probably due to inexperience with UE4, frames randomly dip in certain areas
[/list]

This is a tough one. Ultimately, I liked the game, but it had plenty of lows, where I cursed either the inexperience of the devs, or lack of time and money. In the end, I am happy I have invested my time into it. I wouldn't say the game wastes your time, but it's demanding and can be intimidating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008331676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 868, 'last_played': 1641080621}
review: A solid game. It's a little clunky in places, but pretty engaging. It took me a while to figure out that you really do need to explore the entire map in order to acquire everything you need to succeed. Once I did that, the game progressed swiftly. It has some really neat mechanics. If you're not into platformers, though, it's probably not the game for you. There is a LOT of climbing. (and dying)

review:
Tried every fix I can find, but the game crashes to desktop when starting a new game. Can't comment on the gameplay since I haven't been able to play.
Tried running as admin, tried disabling all relevant in game overlays, restarting, validating files et-cetera. Game won't run for more than thirty seconds and CTD.
Before you assume its my computer, I can run Cyberpunk 2077 on max settings with 60fps on a 1920x1080 monitor. It's the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967648495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2250, 'last_played': 1638661654}
review:
Played from early access. Skipped awhile, then played a year after it was released.  It's a fun romp worth the money.   For the most part it played flawlessly on my PC.  The parkour wasn't bad.  The level design was good.   If you don't do things in the order the intended, things don't happen to progress the story.   What I mean is the suggested "do next" is really the only way to play it.  

The final boss fight got kinda of staggary but not enough to cause me to fail it. 

The stealth is limited.  You can't take down an enemy with a single sneak attack. Once you get the cross-bow though you can start hunting the bad guys. 

I recommend it.  I wish the horror was a little more horrible but it was good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981405537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1839, 'last_played': 1637888411}
review:
This game was a surprise gem in a Humble Bundle - I wound up liking it a lot more than I expected I would.  The island setting is beautiful, the pacing is good, and the horror elements underlying the whole thing are well done.

The platforming segments are where the game really shines.  The jumps are brutal, and you'll see the Load Game screen many, many times during the longer sequences.  But the save points are placed generously enough to prevent things from getting frustrating, and it's genuinely a joy to reach the top of a tough climb.

The story is pretty good as well: you wake up on an cultish island where half the population is drugged out of their minds, the other half are working in slavery under the illusion of freedom, inconvenient people tend to disappear or worse, and the guys at the top are a bunch of hypocrites and phonies who decry the ills of modern society while living off its largesse.  In other words, your typical socialist paradise. Your job is to explore the island and survive long enough to find a way to escape (or, if you prefer, join the Community).

The biggest beef I have with the game, aside from the occasional graphical stuttering, is the boss fights.  For a game built around exploration and stealth, it's quite jarring and immersion-breaking to suddenly wind up in a closed arena in straight-up combat.  The mid-game boss isn't too bad, but the final one is just awful; it's a terrible ending to what is otherwise a very enjoyable game.

Boss fights aside, I heartily recommend this game to fans of open-world exploration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068084583', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1657818076}
review: Die Young is a survival 'jump-climb' crafting horror game which you will remember just because of the pretty unique setting of the game. It has a nice storyline where you have to unravel the mysteries of your friends and about the island. The game has very good audio-effects in my opinion (like getting detected/ during a fight). Especially when you are walking through the cornfield for the first time is an... 'unique' moment in the game ;). The AI during a fight is kinda easy though. Just throw a few rocks - evade backwards - and continue throwing rocks is easier than some slashing with a weapon. In my opinion that shouldn't be possible. The graphics are great and you can put the view distance extremely high. There are a few glitches though, like crawling close next to a tree and picking up an item will result sometimes in getting stuck. So my advice is to save regularly on a new save file (so not quicksaving)! Definately recommanding this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197998351513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1224, 'last_played': 1636543611}
review:
No suelo hacer reseÃ±as, la verdad, de hecho, esta va a ser la primera que haga recomendando un juego.

No me voy a extender, si estas dispuesto a pasar por alto unos graficos tipicos de juego indie, lejos de Triple A, y una IA enemiga bastante lamentable, este juego es de las mejores sorpresas que me he llevado en aÃ±os. Un argumento solido y adulto, detalles bien atados, objetos y recursos que estan donde tienen que estar. No encontraras municion en la mesa de una cocina, o un botiquin en el cadaver de un jabalÃ­. Aqui todo esta atado minuciosamente y al detalle. Nunca suelo leerme los textos o lores que encuentras en los juegos, pero en este todo esta resumido a un texto corto que no rompe el ritmo, y atado perfectamente con el momento, situacion o lugar donde lo encuentras, incluso en el aspecto del papel que te encuentras. No es lore Â·porque si". 

Los desarrolladores consiguen que empatices con las historias y personajes (cadaveres en su mayoria) que encontraras, todos en situaciones completamente creibles y realistas. Los escenarios, son otra obra de arte, es cierto que a veces desesperan por su complejidad (mencion especial a la primera vez que llegas al pinar y a la zona de la torre alta), pero de alguna manera, te picas, el juego te obliga a orientarte y recompensa la exploracion con esas historias tan buenas, o con objetos utiles. La orientacion es otro punto que me gustaria resaltar, porque si bien al principio te puedes quejar de no poder ver el mapa completo, al final te das cuenta de que ese hecho hace que te posiciones y te esmeres mas en saber donde estas y como volver a otros sitios a pie.

La longitud del juego es perfecta, ni corto, ni largo. No me he quedado con ganas de mas, ni me ha parecido largo.

La banda sonora, pese a ser escueta, esta MUY bien escogida, dandole ese toque de pelicula de serie B.

El control y fluidez de juego tambien merece mencion especial. Ha habido momentos donde me he sentido de nuevo como en 1998 con el Tomb Raider I y sus saltos dificiles. Aqui no iran los saltos carrileados como en otros juegos, que parece que vas imantado hacia donde ienes que llegar. O calculas, o te matas. Muy muy buen parkour.

En serio, si te gusta la supervivencia, la aventura, y la exploracion, juega a este juego. Me ha parecido MUCHO mejor que Dying Light, y casi al nivel de Farcry 3 (en algunos aspectos lo supera bastante). Es una pena que la IA y variedad de los enemigos sea tan limitada, asi como el combate. Si hubieran pulido ese aspecto un poco mas, seria un 10 de 10, no un 9. Pero bueno, en su defensa dire que combate hay poco, todo se basa mas en la exploracion.

De verdad, probadlo. Y NO JUGUEIS PRIMERO AL PROLOGO, os dara una impresion muy mala, al lado de lo que es el juego, porque basicamente te meten de entrada lo peor del juego, que es el combate, y en un escenario que es bastante asquerosillo. Jugadlo al final, tras superar el juego, asi tambien lo entendereis mejor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964066027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1269, 'last_played': 1636325397}
review:
Tl;Dr:
Climbing puzzles, stealth, and pretty landscapes to fall off.
Get ready to die young.

The deets:
Looking at the reviews, I guess someone's gotta say it
The game is called "Die Young". If you play this, then whine about dying young, clearly ya didn't read the title.
OK, that put of the way.
If you've played the more recent Tomb Raider games, you'll get an idea for this one. You're dropped in the middle of nowhere, and beside a backstory of "rich dad, who was extremely outdoorsy", you're playing a glass ornament who will not survive combat with an angry pillow. There is no levelling up. You have to eat and drink to survive. Your gear deteriorates quickly, and you have stamina to contend with too. You fall off a cliff you die. You run in to an angry boar you die. You meet an angry islander, you might not die, but meet their buddy and don't have enough stamina left to flee you die. You climb half way up a cliff face and think you can hang around and think about you will loose grip and die. You will die a lot in this game.
And to add to it, you can save as much as you want... but it costs you crafting materials you probably can't spare because if you use them to save instead of on weapons, you die.
This is a game that throws you in the deep end, and shrugs at you "what you complaining about? We made it fair" and it hurts because you know it's fair, but you're just used to games where the only challenge is whether or not you've stocked enough bullets.
Beyond marking clearly the climbing routes, it makes sure there's a challenge. You only get to see one segment of the map at a time, you're going to have to use the compass as a compass, you're going to have to learn your routes and use your brain. This isn't "challenging through bad design" it's challenging by being challenging, so by the end it feels like an accomplishment.
The only criticism is that the crossbow is so dramatically over powered, that the combat switches from "oh sh~ I'm gonna die" to "Urgh let's just check I have some bolts left". For an example of how over powered, the knife deals about 12, absorbs stamina, and has to be crafted after a few uses, the crossbow deals about 120 and only needs bolts.
Added to this, the challenge in the game is reflected in the story. While the "rich kid does something stupid" backstory did make it hard to empathise at times, all the way through you're getting this feeling of "am I the bad guy here?" at every turn.
And to top all that off, this is just a gorgeous looking game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199074876499', 'num_games_owned': 2168, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 2002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1636742048}
review:
Received this game as part of a bundle. The world looks great but there are some serious problems which really hold this game back. 

Travelling is tiring in this game. From the go, you feel lost, spending 90% of the game time climbing rocks trying to find a cave where you can do some fast travel, which still happens to be miles away from where missions are. 

The combat is terrible- It doesn't feel natural. You find your character exhaused after throwing two swings, meaning the 30 minutes of climbing those mountains is lost. 

The glitches. Probably mentioned a thousand times before by other reviewers are little niggles that the devs should have ironed out. But couldn't be bothered doing. 23 hours in I encountered a game breaking bug where a body is stuck in an elevator. I couldn't progress further into the game and had to find a save 4 hours in the past to actually continue to finishing the game. I did send an email to the developer but never received a reply.

Having completed the game I can honestly say I wouldn't recommend the game. The developer has clearly moved on from the PC version and is now focusing on the playstation version. 


Such a shame. 6/10 



Positives: 

- The graphics are nice. 
- Decent map size 
-Nice soundtrack


Negatives
-Abandoned by the developer now the PS5 version is out (Disgraceful)
- Terrible combat 
-Confusing navigation 
- Game breaking bugs 
- Bosses who disappear for no apparent reason (meaning the achievement can't be got)
-Poor storyline

author: {'steamid': '76561198006525169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1636272141}
review:
I was really enjoying it until the forced platforming sections. The coastal tower killed me twice and I gave up. You can't save unless you have wood, and it is really hard to acquire wood. For reasons. There are small trees and what looks like branches everywhere, but no wood. So, its not like I could just save at a critical jump which if you miss, you'll fall and die. 

It feels like a rip on the Elder Scrolls way of having unpickable locks everywhere, but if you get to the other side of a door, it is no longer locked. If I had the option to skip some of the platforming, like the coastal tower, I might have kept playing it, but the climbing is fairly janky in this game and the things that can be grabbed with a sprint jump isn't entirely clear. 

Up to the coastal tower I was really enjoying this open world survival experience, but this killed all interest in the title for me. Its not like Rise of the Tomb Raider with clear climbing mechanics and constant autosaves. You fail a jump, and you have to redo the entire platforming puzzle.

No thanks. Not my cup of tea. I liked the way Rise of the Tomb Raider did climbing and parkour (originally what attracted me to the title as it felt like a cross between Far Cry 3 and Rise). I don't like the climbing and parkour in this one. So just be aware that there are forced climbing puzzles and if you fail them you'll have to restart all of it. Otherwise I decent title marred by a stupid design decision. 

I played on the normal difficulty. I cannot see how Survival mode would be doable as there is so little food and water and nothing respawns (as far as I can tell).

author: {'steamid': '76561198821619279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1635612218}
review:
This is not really a bad game. Its a good game with bad design element. The combat is meh which I kinda anticipated anyway. Its parkour is let's say between Mirror's Edge and Dying Light (average), DL perfected that mechanic. The world is beautiful to run around with.

The cons of this game is the map design, In first area you can go to a specific location in a lot of direction you can but when you got in the middle game it starts to funnel you to a series of routes that is so confusing. Pinewoods was its intro in how annoyingly to navigate an area. When I got to the Stone Pillars I got frustrated are there are so many climbing routes to take and hard to remember where they will end up. 

I could have accept this if the map update and actually show the routes I have taken to better navigate areas but nope map is as obsure in showing path just as in the beginning. This game is design to be confusing to make the game time long is not good to me. If only the dev put QOL in navigating confusing areas I would have enjoyed just running around everywhere. 

That is just my take if you have no problem wasting time trying to mental map all the routes then this game may give you enjoyment. For me I just can't waste my time trying to remember how to get to where.

author: {'steamid': '76561198349342447', 'num_games_owned': 1891, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 1605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1605, 'last_played': 1634969715}
review:
Scores: Excellent, Very Good, Good, Bad, Very Bad, Awful.
- Performance: Very Good (Some frame drops here and there - 60 fps, 1440p res).
- Art style: Very Good (You will spend most of the time in rocky areas, green fields, sunny days)
- Gameplay: Very Good (Parkour and crafting....both are ok, combat not that much)
- Story: Very Good (Interesting from the very beginning, till the end.
- Sound, Music, Voice: Bad (After the game ended, I realized an option called "streamer mode" was on, so probably this was the reason why the music was all over the place. Sound and voice were also not very good).

For me, this is one of the best games I've played this year. I had so much fun, I could not stop playing. Strongly recommended for those that have played Dying Light.

author: {'steamid': '76561199111298174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1632707638}
review:
No digo que sea un superjuegazo de esos que recordarÃ© siempre, pero lo he disfrutado (y sufrido) bastante. Me sorprende mucho que sÃ³lo tenga una calificaciÃ³n media de "variadas" en las reseÃ±as. No sÃ©, tal vez muchos esperaban un juego de acciÃ³n (es verdad que el trailer puede ser engaÃ±oso), cuando en realidad es un juego de exploraciÃ³n, caza, crafteo, y mucho (muchÃ­simo) parkour. El combate (no es combate abierto, es de combinarlo con sigilo) estÃ¡ concentrado en el Ãºltimo tercio del juego y en unas pocas boss fights.  Es con cuchillo, melee, ballesta o molotov (no hay armas de fuego) y no es exigente. El parkour, que es la mecÃ¡nica principal del juego, sÃ­ que lo es (algunas zonas, muy especialmente la subida hacia la torre, son una tortura...) y preparaos para despeÃ±aros bastantes veces. La isla ficticia turca donde transcurre el juego es un mundo abierto  con hogueras donde salvar la partida y refugios para recuperar salud, dormir y hacer viajes rÃ¡pidos a otras zonas. Aunque a veces hay que buscar una aguja en un pajar, la exploraciÃ³n, incluso con lo incÃ³modo del mapa a trozos, no se me ha hecho complicada.  

Si tienes claro que lo que mÃ¡s vas a tener que hacer es parkour y explorar, es un muy buen juego, yo lo recomiendo sin duda. Si tienes fuertes sentimientos animalistas mejor no lo juegues porque para sobrevivir vas a tener que cazar bastante. Puedes comer sÃ³lo de las latas que encuentres, pero para aumentar el tamaÃ±o de la mochila (con el tamaÃ±o inicial lo tienes crudo...) necesitas piel. Y no veas como chillan los pobres jabalÃ­s, zorros, cabras, etc cuando los matas :-( 

En cuanto al prÃ³logo/precuela es en el estilo de sigilo/combate del Ãºltimo tercio del juego principal. De cara a disfrutar mÃ¡s de la trama segÃºn se van atando cabos, recomiendo jugar primero el prÃ³logo. 

Sin spoilear, el juego principal tiene tres finales. Dos de ellos (los llamo A y B) siempre estarÃ¡n disponibles, suceden en un sitio y terminar en A o B  sÃ³lo depende de que llegues antes de las 9 am (te lo dirÃ¡n expresamente) o no a ese sitio (en realidad si llegas tarde es que lo has hecho a propÃ³sito). El otro final (C) sÃ³lo estarÃ¡ disponible si en un momento del juego tomas una decisiÃ³n (en una playa). Si la tomas te invitarÃ¡n a ir a un sitio,  y si decides ir y haces allÃ­ una Ãºltima cosa tiene lugar el final C y se acaba la partida. No estÃ¡s obligado, puedes o no ir nunca o ir mucho mÃ¡s tarde (de hecho el juego dura un tercio mÃ¡s, aparte de todos los detalles de la trama que quedan por revelar!). Mi consejo es que continÃºes la trayectoria hacia los finales A/B y cuando salga la cita de las 9 am que he dicho antes haz un guardado que podrÃ¡s usar para llegar a los tres finales.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025321433', 'num_games_owned': 1160, 'num_reviews': 452, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 655, 'last_played': 1634791488}
review:
Die Young is definitely one of the more empty games I have played lately. Over the 11 hours that it took me to complete this game I had very mixed feelings. You are held captive on an island and have to undergo some trials to escape or maybe even join the weird cult that inhabits it. You can pretty much freely explore said island, though there is a clear way the story wants you to go, which is fine.

The game has some good parts. It looks pretty good and runs well. The island is somewhat lackluster in its design and largely looks the same everywhere, but still conveys a sense of beauty. There are notes scattered that explain (very) few things about the story and the islands inhabitants. The game has a lot of climbing sections, and while it's no Dying Light, it gets the job done. Some of those sections are pretty cool and give you some awesome views.

Fighting is meh. Most enemies die from one headshot with the crossbow, and you want to do that, because melee fighting is unresponsive and quickly leads to demise - unless you have a Harpoon, which has an increased reach and is without a doubt the best melee weapon. Still, when in doubt, shoot a crossbow.

As I explored the story and slowly advanced in the game, some questions started to form in my mind. Mostly: "why am I doing this"? The island is open to exploration, but there is not much to be seen aside from a few landmarks. In true Far Cry fashion there are plants everywhere you can use to craft things, but your inventory is limited to 5 spaces (which is terribly little) unless you do very specific side quests or find one item that you can very easily run past. Accidentally miss said item (in a side area)? Well, you can never expand your inventory by crafting new bags. Sucks to be you.

In general, the game is chock full of bad or weird design decisions like the one above. The story doesn't really start unless you follow the main path a bit, and since you can explore from the start, you will be killing a lot of guys without even really knowing why. Even later on, though, the story is very confusing and the game does a poor job of explaining what's going on. Because exploring is so lackluster and there is not much to find, combined with the maze-like design of later areas, the game quickly tests your patience in the worst way. This all culminates in an awful final boss fight that must have been designed by someone who has no idea what they are doing - that is the only way to describe it. I can't remember the last time I actually cheated in a game, but that fight made me do it, no shame.

Overall, the best way to describe the game is pointless. You wander around like a chicken without a head on a mostly empty island where the only thing that attacks you for 80 % of the game are random dogs, boars or wolves. You won't know what you are doing or why you are even on the island for most of the game, and by the end barely any questions will be answered and more questions will appear. There is barely any gameplay aside from climbing or shooting a crossbow, there are weird design decisions in terms of area design and inventory limits and the protagonist has the charisma of an unripened grapefruit. And the map - I have NEVER seen a more useless video game map in my life. Only the chunk you are currently in is displayed and you can never see a map of the entire island. It is absolutely terrible design that has no real use or purpose.

If you want to play this game, but good and actually as a game, play Far Cry 3 or later. While I certainly admire the effort of building up this relatively large island and letting the player roam mostly free, it doesn't do much good if there is no game to go with it and if most decisions just seem to be designed to frustrate the player. Stay far away.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970565613', 'num_games_owned': 444, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1468, 'last_played': 1634294802}
review:
Die Young is an ok game that feels like a well done Half Life 2 mod.
Its politics are a mess and the 'streamer mode' not turning off was annoying but most of the game was fun.

Parkour high on a beach cliff is worth a sale price, but I'm unable to recommend because the final boss sequence is too unbalanced.
I was pretty bored of the game by the end and to face a brutal mega-health bullet-sponge with a couple pointy sticks and one molotov was a momentum killer and game ender. 

This one goes on a very short list of games I didnt finish.
Cheers.

author: {'steamid': '76561199092559999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1630885312}
review: I want to love this game, I really do. The graphics are impressive for such a small team. I am fully invested in the plot, the main character and how her story will end. But I am extremely frustrated with two things: 1) The crashing. The game crashes pretty constantly. And if you don't have a save point nearby and put in an hour or more of work and the game crashes you are screwed. 2) There is no direction whatsoever. I understand there is supposed to be an air of mystery and uncertainty, but there are times where there is no direction whatsoever on what you're supposed to do or where you are supposed to go. The sense button does not light up documents or other clues so you quite literally have to search every nook and cranny to find them, which can be tedious and time consuming. All in all, I think the crashing is the biggest downfall of this game. If the devs could add just a tad bit more clarity by giving players a little bit more push in the right direction, or possibly some hints, they can maintain the realism while not leaving us completely in the dark.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980083098', 'num_games_owned': 342, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 2690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1484, 'last_played': 1674987575}
review:
This game is an outstanding adventure.
Even though the performance has some issues (occasional stutter), its atmosphere and immersion are awesome (especially when playing without HUD).
Which gives me enough reason to overlook these stutter issues and enjoy the game.

Maybe it reminds me about Far Cry Primal a bit (not story- or time-wise, but the gameplay with collecting herbs, crafting stuff and having no guns), is the reason why I totally fell for it.
The parkour elements are on a similar level as for Mirror's Edge or Dying Light.

Whatever it is, after recording a playthrough, I had to play it once more.
If you are used to the game, it's easy to beat it within 6 hours or less, so it doesn't take that long overall.

The story itself is a bit weird, but there are dozens over dozens of notes that give a lot background info and if you rest in a shelter a series of small comic strips will be played that give your charakter "Daphne" even more background.
These comic strips repeat themselves after having seen them all, but you can skip EVERY comic or movie sequence this game offers to speed things up, if you already know it or simply don't care about, but rathrer want to play the game for the fast paced parkour action and not the weird story. ^^


I think this game makes a perfect challenge for yourself. Playing through with own rules like not killing anyone except the enemies at the end boss fight.
At some point I might get back to the game and play it with such personal restrictions.

Last but not least, here is my recorded playthrough, which I only do on games I really like:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLaaMs9hziB80HeeefNQknXX58nVhg5wBu
NO HUD.

And one challenge playthrough of around 5 hrs.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2602397290
I've used the HUD in this one and realized the quest update often gets bugged in screen. :/
It can be removed by opening the inventory.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124433088', 'num_games_owned': 56, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 965, 'last_played': 1630248986}
review:
Open world, elements of survival, a lot of climbing, a lot of skinning animals, especially foxes, running away from wild boars, smiting those socialist-cult bastards with a crowbar, finding secrets, mixing herbs, draining those snakes of their venom :D 
with a special tool that an old man in the woods gave you. Did I mentioned you're a girl? :D There isn't much of a dialoge in this game, but the progatonist comes out as a typical party girl - as in, not very smart. But hey, since there is a whole island to scale with your bare feet (until you take shoes of your dead friend, yes, there is looting dead bodies in this game). 
There was a lot of thought given in making this game, and I guarantee it will draw you in it. Scenery is gorgeous, mostly due to the light. Textures aren't all that amazing though, but it doesn't subtracts the joy of playing. It is a very good overall. 
This is my third playthrough. And I don't usually re-play games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083068272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 2189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2189, 'last_played': 1625940183}
review:
Awakened in a hole masquerading as an early grave, marooned on a hostile island, separated from your friends and with only one option available, escape or die, Die Young puts the player in the shoes of a young woman caught up in a desperate war to survive when her and her friends are attacked by a vicious cult on a paradise getaway.  It's about time I did some kind of review for this one as I had supported Die Young through Early Access all the way through to its final release.  While the game does have its flaws, the overall enjoyable experience present across the game's lengthy campaign should make for a fun time for players that enjoy a horror theme but need at least a brief break from the corroded corridors, abandoned buildings and confining mansions that have completely usurped the genre over the last few years (I'm still a sucker for a good mansion though). 

After climbing out of the aforementioned hole, it's certainly apparent that DY is pretty nice looking.  On the highest settings the lush foliage of the forests, vast rolling plains of the island itself, scenic hills and vistas and the sunlight skies cast down upon the player are certainly a breathtaking sight.  They did a great job here especially with distance and scale because the higher you climb some of the towering mountain peaks or the deeper you gaze into some of the game's forgotten ruins and swallowing caves, you do get the feeling that if you close your eyes you'll be transported away to this exotic paradise.

The presentation isn't flawless as pop-up and some low-res textures on certain surfaces take away from the dreaminess (alongside the average to decent character models and sometimes janky animations) and aren't the most flattering aspects of the design.  Sound is likewise a mixed bag hovering above average with serviceable voice-acting, decent FX for the angry "want to kill you locals" and savage animals thirsty for your blood as a trippy, trance-y Unreal like musical theme unveils itself as you explore.  Overall, things and look sound tight and keep you in the fight without ever quite ringing of, "Wow, this looks and sounds perfect!"  

It's the gameplay loop that DY brings to the table that kept me aboard for two completions; one towards the very end of Early Access on normal and one after its release on Survival.  I'm going to definitely recommend that more experienced FPS players go with Survival as the other setting was a bit too easy.  On Survival you actually need to pay closer attention to your thirst/stamina, have less resources to craft healing kits, weapons and other key items and the enemies have more gusto in their blunt force attacks.  

You've got a fairly sprawling map to with numerous locations to discover and explore.  Your progress will be hard fought until you can unlock some of the fast travel shrines.  Additional objectives appear in your journal as you find places you can't get into or obstacles that you can't pass.  These will require either keys, a recipe for a certain upgrade or other solutions.  Items break down into equipables (clothing that you can find by scouring the map that provides several direct upgrades; speed, defense, climbing bonuses, etc.), healing kits and poison cures, hand to hand or long range weaponry, ingredients to craft items, wood to build campfires (needed for saving at a checkpoint, creating an on the go fire that you can quick save at, having a heat source to cook meat with to make it edible), documents/journal entries, etc.  One of the most satisfying things about DY for me was exploring every nook and cranny of the island completely and seeing what different things you can find.  There is a real sense of discovery the more places that you marked as visited on the map and the fuller your inventory gets.  Though the crafting is far from in-depth when compared to some other games, the overall loot and inventory system in the game was a lot of fun to work with.  The interface is also intuitive and not clunky in my opinion, which is the make or break for a game where you are going to be using it frequently.   

Exploration is what gives this title its juice.  You run, slide, crouch, jump, sneak, attack and perform a diverse array of parkour and assorted moves to get around the place while staying alive.  The control is mostly fluid and easy to get down pat on mouse/keyboard.  Get used to climbing and jumping Dying Light/Prince of Persia style because there are some absolutely vertigo-inducing locations to explore.  There's certain gear to find that gives you advantages in the peaks but mostly you'll be shimmying hand over hand, looking for ways to ascend higher and then taking daring, white-knuckle leaps to catch a ledge you are aimed at.  You'll also be saying the F-word from time to time as every now and then you'll think you have the ledge in your crosshair, take a lily pad launch with arms akimbo and somehow miss as you crunch like breakfast cereal on the rocks below.  It wasn't a frequent occurrence but it will happen, really ruin your day and make you unapproachable afterwards in public.  Mostly the mistakes I made were my fault yet prepare yourself for a quirk or two that will leave you scratching your head.  Still, as stated earlier the visual scale when you are pulling these moves off will have your heart in throat throughout.  It's the best part of DY and it's executed with a flair that gives it its own flavor when compared to Dying Light, Mirror's Edge and other similar experiences.  

When you're not performing a platforming extravaganza, doing extensive ground-level exploration and crafting, the remainder of the game is based upon combat.  You'll face your foes with an assortment of knives, wrenches, crowbars, batons, sticks, shovels and rocks.  This is probably the shakiest part of DY but once I got settled in to how basic the combat was, I had fun with it, though don't expect to be wowed because I wasn't.  You can do a quick strike, charged up haymaker and block.  That's it.  Handheld weapons all function in the same way except for their differences in damage, speed and range.  For the tougher areas and boss fights, you'll eventually be armed with a crossbow that can zoom in.  It too is bare bones though, but picking off enemies from a distance and then going in and cleaning up the weak woman to man is actually a fair amount of fun.  Enemy A.I. is so/so with some pathfinding issues though they'll decimate you from range with a crossbow and completely manhandle you if you get caught reloading by a mixed group that includes dogs.  It's not insanely difficult but you can die if you make dumb choices.  Though by the end of the game I was a killing machine with almost every weapon in my arsenal and a surplus of crossbow arrows. 

From time to time you'll encounter hulking boss characters that roam the islands whom you can either fight or skip (though fighting and winning yields achievements and items that you can't find elsewhere).  Even scarcer are a couple of scripted boss battles that required more traditional pattern studying and a specific strategy.  They weren't great battles but I thought they were fairly fun (mainly the final fight) and I appreciated them breaking up the action.  There's even some choices to make that can change the story's outcome ever so slightly, so there are reasons to play the game a second time if you really want to aside from bumping up the difficulty.  

Die Young is flawed but fun.  There's also a prologue expansion available for even more thrills that flesh out some of the story beats even further.  I'd say for fans of this genre should give it a check...on a sale if you're unsure and even for full-price if you're sold since the tag is certainly reasonable for what you get.  8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198188736722', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 1264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1264, 'last_played': 1627156772}
review:
This game looks promising yet unfinished. Developers abandoned their discord server as well as the game. 

1. Realism - 0/10 
2. Stealth - 0/10 
3. Combat - 1/10
4. Parcour - 4/10 (since you can climb in specifically designed places only, so the map is surely "straight-forward")
5. World - 7/10 (pretty big for the walking game, but we have teleport features; also pretty limited)
6. Hidden locations - 9/10 (not bad at all)
7. UI - 5/10
8. Controller support - 7/10 (you can't re-assign buttons, only swap them, which will make 'em useless for another UI)
9. Actively supported by devs - 0/10 (they abandoned it)
10. Navigation/map - 3/10 (Map only available from inventory UI. The map is divided into blocks, so you can only see the area you are in. Even though you have a compass and tasks list accessible by the hot key. ðŸ™„)

Overall, as you may calculate, my score of this game is 36%

author: {'steamid': '76561199027668311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 975, 'last_played': 1653753198}
review: The games really fun and came out of left field for me. The combat is somewhat challenging until you get the crossbow and one shot everybody. The climbing feels fun and actually dangerous, until you climb a latter and then it sucks ass. Everything else was fun and nothing was noteworthily bad, but the game has a couple bugs that made me have to reload sometimes so thats probably the biggest downfall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272343837', 'num_games_owned': 555, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 775, 'last_played': 1675853937}
review:
Amazing open-world game, with an interesting story, had much fun playing it.
+ Parkour, lore, environment
- Glitches like getting stuck in a tree while at The Temple of Hope, crashing while alt+tabbing often.

Overall the game is 7,5/10 - so get it if you can, for the price definitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001403943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1973, 'last_played': 1627551999}
review:
I finished the game with 100% achievments and realy enjoyed playing this game.
-Story and atmosphere are great. I was looking forward to find a new piece of information about what happend on the island all the time.
-Climbing / jumping was hard but fun.
-Graphics are quit good.
-But: Its not a tripple A title. So expect some edges. Espcially fighting could be smoother.
I realy hope, developers will make a second part one day!

author: {'steamid': '76561198128425249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 891, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 891, 'last_played': 1625814483}
review:
First off, a disclaimer: This game is nothing like the Forest. I honestly do not know why other reviewers made the comparison. The two games are completely different in focus, scope, and genre. Die Young is a game that for me was a death of a thousand cuts. I was ready to give this a thumbs up, but because it is impossible to have a middling rating, I had to go with the rating that it was leaning more strongly towards. There are simply just too many problems that add up to make the game just not feel fun to play, and that is sad, because the game "is" fun for the most part.

Let us address positives first. The graphics look good. I did not suffer any frame rate drops or graphical issues. I never had a crash, despite bugs, which is always nice. It was a very stable experience. Daphne, the main character, controls well. In a game that requires high execution from the player, I never felt that the controls betrayed me. It always devolved into user error if I failed. As for the core gameplay, the game is heavy on climbing. You will be climbing for what is easily 80% of the game. The game is best when you are just climbing and navigating the verticality of the environment.

The reason the climbing is so engaging is that each jump feels dangerous. So often in games that incorporate parkour elements it feels that your character is superhuman. They make impossible leaps with their freakish grip strength doing sideways dismounts to grab a grip narrower than their own hand about 8 feet away. Here though? Daphne, despite having high grip strength, and able to do some ludicrous jumps, never feels like she is easily doing it. If you are doing a large leap of faith to stick a landing that is about 12 feet away and is slightly higher? Daphne smacks against the rock face with this sickening thud, and her hands frantically scrape at the rock to help pull herself up. Each jump, every single one, feels like death, and it is so exhausting in a good way because you feel completely immersed in her situation. However, the game falls apart everywhere else that by the time you even get to the climbing sections you are worn out from the rest of the game. Regrettably, let us dive into the negatives.

Story wise, Die Young is boring, with practically no payoff at the end. You and your friends are kidnapped and taken to an island at some undisclosed location near Turkey. When you are not climbing, you are exploring the island to satisfy quests and learn more about why you ended up there. The game expects you to care about the story, but all you will want to be doing is climbing, not following breadcrumbs. Even if you were invested in the story, the way it conveys info to you is underwhelming. Daphne can dream when sleeping which allows you to get a bit more backstory into her character. The problem is that this exposes Daphne as an uninteresting, one-dimensional character. When getting information about the island, its worse. You can talk to a few locals, but they basically say the same thing about how the island is this wonderful oasis untouched by the outside world. Then of course you have some note collectibles that go more into other survivors and how they ended up here, which honestly are the more interesting parts of the game story wise.

Sound design is rough. So rough in fact that if you want to have any chance of maintaining your sanity you 100% need to turn the music off. There is this awful bug with the music where transition from zone to zone causes the tracks to bleed over and overlay one another. If it is not doing that, it does not complete the track once it plays, where it will do any number of things be it fade out, double over itself, or just halt abruptly. The music simply does not function properly. Shame, because the music is good, albeit a bit tonally dissonant from the game itself. Aside from the music, the rest of the sound is ok. The ambient noises are super nice, and the game becomes better with the music off. 

Then there is the map. The map is essentially useless. There is very little in the way of similarity between what the map in your current area depicts vs what is in front of you. Even when you are in a larger area, the map does not scale up a level to show higher fidelity; it just maintains its current scale. What that means is when you encounter something like a bonfire, you get this large icon in place of where it is, but does not scale down appropriately; it maintains its scale. So, if it was not already bad enough to try and use the map, after some exploring you really will not be able to make out anything once it populates with your findings. You also do not have the ability to stitch together areas from your previous locations to look at the whole map, only the panel you are in. This is unacceptable in a game that is not only open world, but so reliant on you exploring it. What the hell at not having a button or way to view the entire map? This easily is one of the worst parts of the game by far. Terrible decision.

I will touch on the combat quick. It really does not matter, and the game makes it incredibly easy to ignore encounters so you could bypass most of it by running away. Hunting is just another way to increase carrying capacity, and fighting the humans grant you access to either a baton or a crossbow. Other than that, you can ignore combat completely. Survival wise, I really do not see the point in having it in the game. Water resources are so bountiful that it is trivial to monitor your thirst. You do not have a hunger meter, eating is tied to your health like most other games, so you do not need to hunt. Just craft some healing items from flowers or forage berries and you are good to go. 

Finally, let us discuss navigating the world. As mentioned previously, when you are in the climbing segments, the game is at its best. Reaching the climbs, however, are not as clear because the signposting in the game is highly misleading.  The main way the game denotes where you should go or what is climbable are very light white paint steaks on surfaces. For the most part, it works. However, Die Young does not always denote climbable surfaces with this. In other games, usually following signposting is the one true way of progress. Here though, you will encounter many times a situation where you are expected to ascend, but you must take switchbacks up and around to another area where there are other white marks but those are not related to the ones you just followed. If you want to stay on path, you will first have to climb an area that does not look climbable because it does not have that mark, and then you are back on the right path. It is not very clear in what it wants from the player in most cases, and combined with the map issues I mentioned earlier, it is incredibly frustrating to get your bearings in new areas.
 
The game would have been better off just having a level structure. Just drop the open world thing entirely. The game already shows you only one square of a map at a time. That square could be the stage. The squares are already reasonably large and open, so you get to maintain the feeling of exploration and a lite open world motif, without encountering situations where you accidentally tread off the map square into another one. I would just throw up some very clear boundaries to keep the player in that area. If it were done this way, progression would be clearer, and it helps the player out in getting their bearings far easier. The game already feels like it was designed to be more level based than open. All in all, I completed the game and got one of the three endings, and I enjoyed it when the game just let me play it for its strength which was the climbing. I downright despised the other elements and found it completely underwhelming and disappointing how the game forces you to interact with all those other things.  Therefore the game scores a thumbs down from me, even though the climbing gameplay is a strong thumbs up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974002462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 1191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1191, 'last_played': 1625947065}
review:
Ehhhh - There's something mediocre overall about this game. I'd say if you're exceptionally bored and this is cheap, check it out otherwise you aren't missing anything skipping it.

The only thing that kept me going was an interest in how the story shook out and mystery. There's parkour like Dying Light/Mirror's Edge, combat, crafting, and a ton of goats. Was hoping for more mystery like the show Lost and some complete resolution to the story (unlike Lost). 

There's some irregular progression (heavy backtracking), prolonged parkour sections, difficulty in finding the fast travel/shelter points, oddly bad voice acting, boring combat mechanics, and pretty much no stealth mechanics other than hiding in tall grass or far away. There was little to no payoff with the multiple endings I encountered (I just saved before key decisions, definitely didn't replay the game).

author: {'steamid': '76561197974384765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1625335042}
review:
Game was interesting until I came across a fat guy that threw rocks with aimbot. I'm not even kidding, even if you're behind him and he throws a rock, the rock will magically fly backwards and hit you. You think maybe if you run you can dodge the rock? Nope, it literally homes in on you, no matter where you are, whether you're running or standing still or even whether or not the fat guy is turned towards you.
Someone looked at this and went "yep, this looks good. Ship it!"

Final veredict: don't bother

review: Questo gioco, incredibilmente sottovalutato, Ã¨ un piccolo gioiello tutto italiano. Difficile catalogarlo in un genere, in quanto Ã¨ un mix, riuscito, di tanti generi: azione, arrampicata, fuga e soprattutto tanta, tantissima esplorazione. Decine di location da scoprire, strade e scorciatoie da sbloccare, mappa enorme e interconnessa, oggetti e segreti da scoprire per avanzare nella storia, c'Ã¨ davvero tutto quello che deve esserci in un gioco di questo tipo. Gli amanti dell'esplorazione impazziranno. Consigliatissimo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092043493', 'num_games_owned': 676, 'num_reviews': 332, 'playtime_forever': 841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 841, 'last_played': 1623304591}
review:
Quando eu vi die young na steam, pensei que seria mais um daqueles joguinhos genÃ©ricos de terror mal feitos, com um clichÃª chatinho e uma histÃ³ria contada com o traseiro, mas para minha surpresa o jogo Ã© muito alÃ©m do que eu esperava. Obviamente nÃ£o vou comparar com os gigantes lanÃ§ados em 2019, atÃ© porque a empresa de die young Ã© pequena e com uma expertise nÃ£o muito avanÃ§ada em jogos, entÃ£o vou avaliar como um indie beirando um triple A ( porque com essa qualidade ficou melhor atÃ© que certos triple A) 

Graficamente falando o jogo Ã© bonito, mas nada de muito exagerado ou super realista. Aqui temos algo feito com capricho e artisticamente bonito. Mesmo com efeitos de fumaÃ§a e sangue meio mal feitos, a vegetaÃ§Ã£o e a densidade do cenÃ¡rio Ã© algo muito lindo. Passamos por ruÃ­nas, masmorras, plantaÃ§Ãµes, praias, bases militares, templos, minas e muito mais. O jogo pode nÃ£o ser uma ultra/mega/power inovaÃ§Ã£o grÃ¡fica, porÃ©m Ã© lindo e percebe-se o capricho da equipe de arte.

A histÃ³ria Ã© muito boa, realmente vocÃª Ã© pego de surpresa em muitos momentos, onde vocÃª acha que vai enfrentar algo previsÃ­vel como em outros jogos, porÃ©m aqui o que conta Ã© o preparo e a cautela na hora dos combates. VocÃª estÃ¡ na pele de uma moÃ§a que vive muito bem chamada Daphne, que Ã© viciada em esportes arriscados, festinhas e tudo que essa galera endinheirada inventa pra acabar com a prÃ³pria vida. Um dia esta besta quadrada vai para uma ilha que ninguÃ©m basicamente vai, e acaba sendo raptada por um grupo de malucos e presa em um jogo doentio dentro da ilha. Realmente o inÃ­cio da histÃ³ria Ã© bem sem sal e quase plagiado de um filme de baixa qualidade, mas quando comeÃ§amos a jogar, percebemos que o buraco Ã© bem mais embaixo, e que Daphne estÃ¡ envolvida em um esquema bem mais obscuro do que uma simples ilha com lunÃ¡ticos. A histÃ³ria tem vÃ¡rios desfechos, que sÃ£o gerados a partir do que vocÃª faz no jogo, e eu, com muita sorte ( e alguns tutoriais) consegui fazer o melhor final, porÃ©m nem sempre o melhor final quer dizer que tudo estÃ¡ bem. Temos um total de trÃªs finais, e cada um tem suas condiÃ§Ãµes especÃ­ficas, neste ponto achei legal que o game nÃ£o ficou linear, trazendo escolhas que moldam o fim da campanha.

A gameplay Ã© muito boa, onde o crafting Ã© algo indispensÃ¡vel na gameplay. A exploraÃ§Ã£o de cada canto tambÃ©m Ã© Ãºtil, pois encontramos itens, ingredientes e receitas de crafting muito Ãºteis. A dificuldade Ã© um pouco amarga se jogar no normal, e a minha dica Ã© que nÃ£o jogue na dificuldade mais alta porque o modo normal jÃ¡ oferta uma experiÃªncia 100% satisfatÃ³ria e com bastante desafios. 90% do jogo iremos combater com armas brancas, porÃ©m podemos encontrar a crossbow e utilizÃ¡-la, mas recomendo que guarde muniÃ§Ã£o para casos mais extremos, e sempre atire na cabeÃ§a dos inimigos, pois mata na hora, fazendo vocÃª nÃ£o gastar flechas a toa. Boa parte da campanha vamos ficar no parkour mesmo, porÃ©m os combates sÃ£o bons e respondem bem, e em pouco tempo nos acostumamos.

A trilha sonora Ã© bem boa, sendo produzida essencialmente par ao jogo e combina com a atmosfera, porÃ©m muitas vezes ela toca em momentos inoportunos, fazendo vocÃª se questionar se nÃ£o tem algum inimigo por perto. Este detalhe nÃ£o chega a ser um problema, estÃ¡ mais para um pequeno incÃ´modo.

Bugs: o game tem alguns, como inimigos caindo duros no chÃ£o depois da morte, inimigos trancados e paredes invisÃ­veis ou atÃ© com a I.A. desligando, porÃ©m dificilmente acontecem e nÃ£o chegam a atrapalhar tanto. 

Die young Ã© um game que torci o nariz achando que era mais do mesmo, porÃ©m me surpreendeu de todas as formas positivamente possÃ­veis em um game. Se vocÃª gosta de jogos de terror e com uma atmosfera e histÃ³ria legais, pode comprar que vale a pena.
Nota: 9/10

this is an absolutely charming indie game that surprised me from the get go.
a survival lite game with a Dying Light/Mirrors Edge parkour movement system
combat was pretty basic and voice acting in some parts were pretty bad but the enviorment and exploration was superb
